page.title: 03C.M.Coastal Area (West)
page.content: The South West Peninsula Coast Path runs into Combe Martin from the west above steep shaley cliffs. Notable beaches are Broadsands and Golden Cove, the latter reached by a descent of 208 steps. Beaches are rocky and pebbly with greyish sand exposed at low tide. They are ideal for swimming as there are no dangerous currents. In 1919 a landslide above Golden Cove removed a large slice of the old Ilfracombe road and a new road was cut further inland. The old road is now a gravel path. The partly wooded hillside between the main road and the cliff path, formerly a quarrying area, is called Napps. A further section of the old road still runs from Newberry beach to join the main road at Sandaway Caravan Park.
